title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the Act. It includes improved coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to consolidate export promotion activities, clarify roles of Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee members, include State agency representatives on the committee, and report to Congress on committee activities and improvements to Export.gov. Sec. 106. Report on developing a single window for information about export control compliance. TITLE I--IMPROVED COORDINATION OF EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS
Sec. 201-206: Various initiatives to promote exporting and support small businesses in export activities. Sec. 101 focuses on consolidating export promotion activities and providing information on trade missions and fairs. In amending Section 2312(b) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988, changes include identifying opportunities to consolidate or co-locate offices, coordinating electronic databases, and reallocating resources. The Secretary of Commerce will provide detailed information on Federal and State-led trade missions and activities to better serve US businesses. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988, as amended, will be available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency in measuring and reporting on goals and objectives, including recommendations from the Comptroller. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify department roles in measuring and reporting goals, including Comptroller recommendations. This includes coordination of the TPCC and its member departments and agencies, as well as updating the reference from the "United States National Tourism Organization" to the "United States Travel Association." SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress on the activities of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, and the implementation of specific sections of the FREEDOM Support Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the TPCC's effectiveness in carrying out export promotion activities and interagency working groups on energy. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies to prepare an annual report on the TPCC's performance in carrying out export promotion activities and implementing the strategic plan successfully. The TPCC member definition includes specific congressional committees such as Appropriations, Commerce, Finance, Foreign Relations, Small Business, Energy, and Foreign Affairs. The TPCC member definition includes specific congressional committees such as Appropriations, Commerce, Finance, Foreign Relations, Small Business, Energy, and Foreign Affairs. Financial Services, the Committee on Small Business, and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives are also included. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporting information. The Export.gov website serves as a centralized platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. Small business concerns and various entities involved in export promotion are specified to use this platform. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations, and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
(1) "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator.
(2) "Region of the Administration" is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act.
(3) "Small business concern" is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. Amends the Small Business Act to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting as a business opportunity for small businesses. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers or international clients. At least one matchmaking event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events required under the Small Business Act. The Administrator's authority under this Act will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
